subject: Nutrition
title: The p-Hacking Problem
description: A 60-second lesson on The p-Hacking Problem.

hook.text: Measure enough things and something will look statistically significant purely by random chance.

buildup.text: P-hacking is when researchers test dozens of variables until they find one with a significant p-value.

discovery.text: A p-value under 0.05 means 5% chance the result is random. Test 20 things and one passes by luck.

twist.text: Nutrition research is especially vulnerable because every food contains hundreds of measurable compounds.

climax.text: Pre-registering studiesâ€”declaring what you'll measure before startingâ€”is the best defense.

punchline.text: Test enough variables and you'll find a miracle.

quiz.question: What is p-hacking?
options: Testing many variables until one appears significant by chance
